description: Charitable giving picked up last year after falling in 2022. But inflation is chipping away at the value of gifts, putting a squeeze on donors and non-profits alike.
title: Inflation has driven expenses up for charity groups — while driving donations down

description: To shore up childcare in Arizona, a nonprofit has long focused on training informal caregivers -- the family, friends and neighbors who care for a majority of young children in the state.
title: This Arizona nonprofit helps get informal caregivers everything they need for the job

description: NPR'S Juana Summers speaks with Bob Bauer, the personal lawyer to President Biden, who stood in for Trump and Bernie Sanders in 2020 during mock-debates for the president to prep.
title: An insider’s look at how Biden preps for a debate

description: A new poll from asked Latinos about misinformation and elections. It comes as efforts are underway to combat false narratives targeting Latinos.
title: New research looks at how political misinformation is targeted at Latinos

description: For the first time in almost two months, Israel has allowed a small group of kids to leave Gaza for medical treatment. Aid groups say the move came after U.S. pressure and a court challenge in Israel.
title: Israel let some wounded children leave Gaza for treatment, leaving thousands behind

description: History buffs and tourists get a chance to go 2,300 feet underground to visit a historic mine in Minnesota.
title: Underground tours resume at Minnesota's oldest iron mine

description: Two new rulings have frozen much of Biden's newest student loan repayment plan, arguing that the plan is too generous and setting up another possible student debt reckoning before the Supreme Court.
title: Rulings argue that Biden's student loan repayment plan is too generous

description: Cicadas are the song of the summer, but this year’s large broods may be especially irritating for people on the autism spectrum who have hearing sensitivity.
title: Tips to deal with cicada song, for those with sensory issues

description: Surgeon General Vivek Murthy has declared gun violence a “public health crisis in America.” NPR's Juana Summers talks with Dr. Cedric Dark, an emergency physician who treats gunshot victims.
title: Will calling gun violence a 'public health crisis' change the political conversation?

description: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange has reached a plea deal with the U.S. government. He's expected to plead guilty to conspiring to obtain and disclose information related to the national defense.
title: The latest on Julian Assange's plea deal

description: The war between two armed groups in Sudan has been going on for over a year and has engulfed much of the country. About 12 million people are internally displaced, there is a potential for famine in many parts of the country and there are again fears of genocide in Darfur. The International Rescue Committee has put Sudan at the top of their emergency watchlist and their report says that the international community has failed in Sudan. We talk to the IRC country director about the dire situation.
title: Is the International Community Failing Sudan?

description: Russia’s southern republic of Dagestan continues to mourn loved ones and hold funerals for the dead, as questions and conspiracy theories swirl over the weekend attack that killed 20 people.
title: In Russia, Dagestan mourns and suspicions mount after deadly attacks

description: A new report by independent experts on famine says half a million people in Gaza are now facing starvation as the aid people depend on has dwindled.
title: High risk of famine across Gaza as hunger spreads, experts say

description: Space Camp is a new series about all the weird, wonderful things happening in the universe by NPR's science podcast Short Wave. Check out the rest of the series.
title: From planets to black holes, we look at the oddities of space

description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s campaign manager insists the independent candidate is qualified for this week's presidential debate despite the fact that he did meet the criteria to appear on the stage.
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s campaign downplays polling, fundraising, ballot access woes

description: The former President and leading GOP candidate can now make statements about witnesses and jurors.
title: Donald Trump's gag order partially lifted in New York hush money trial

description: The majority of the families are accusing a set of parents in Texas of attempting a “money grab” that would get them “outsized recoveries.” The trustee has asked the bankruptcy court to intervene.
title: Alex Jones trustee files emergency request as Sandy Hook families battle over assets

description: Thousands of protesters against a new finance bill entered parliament in Nairobi and legislators fled, in the most direct assault on the government in decades in Kenya.
title: Kenya's parliament burns and police shoot at protesters against new taxes

description: The nation's top doctor issued an advisory on Tuesday declaring gun violence a public health crisis and prescribing policy changes to treat it as such. It's both unprecedented and unenforceable.
title: The surgeon general declared gun violence a public health crisis. What does that do?

description: Israel’s high court ruled unanimously that the military must begin drafting ultra-Orthodox men — a decision that could lead to the collapse of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s ruling coalition.
title: Israeli Supreme Court rules that the military must begin drafting ultra-Orthodox men

description: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has agreed to plead guilty in order to return to Australia. Plus, how immigration will feature in Biden and Trump's debate on Thursday.
title: WikiLeaks founder to plead guilty; What to expect at Biden-Trump debate

description: After a long wait and many delays the first contingent of the Kenyan-led international force is on its way to Haiti.
title: Kenya is sending thousands of police officers to tackle Haiti's gang violence

description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Amaryllis Fox Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s campaign manager and daughter-in-law, about the challenges facing Kennedy's independent presidential campaign.
title: There are signs Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s presidential campaign is struggling

description: Assange will plead guilty to a single charge and is expected to return to Australia. The move brings an end to a years-long international saga over his handling of national security secrets.
title: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange enters into a plea deal with the U.S. government

description: Georgia has emerged as one of the swingiest states in politics, so it's no surprise that the first presidential debate happens there. But its voters are less excited for a repeat of the 2020 election.
title: Georgia is hosting the 1st presidential debate. Its voters could decide the election

description: The entertainment industry was shifting dramatically even before the strikes that paused production last year. Now, many Hollywood writers are feeling the pinch.
title: This time last year, Hollywood writers were on strike. Now, many can’t find work
